case_name: Burmah Construction Company v. State of Orissa

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 494 of 1960 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 494 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment dated April 21, 1958 of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 107 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and under dated April 21, 1958 of the Orissa, High Court in O.J.C. No. 107 of 1954.

facts.text: Messrs. Burmah Construction Company carried on business as building and works contractors.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Buarmah Construction Company-a firm carrying on business as building and works companytractors-

facts.text: Burmah Construction Company executed several contracts in the State of Orissa for construction of buildings, roads, bridges etc.

anchor.surface_text: executed several companytracts in the State of Orissa for companystruction of buildings roads, bridges etc.

facts.text: Burmah Construction Company were registered as dealer in Orissa under the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 from the quarters ending June 30, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs. Burmah Construction Company, who are hereinafter referred to as the appellants, were registered as dealer in Orissa under the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 from the quarters ending June 30, 1949.

facts.text: Sales Tax officers assessed the transfer of materials used in the construction as sale of goods and assessed appellants to tax under the Orissa Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax officers treating the transfer of the materials used in the companystruction of the buildings, roads and bridges, as sale of goods, assessed the appellants to tax under the Orissa Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Appellants paid Rs. 1,17,869-8-0 as tax and Rs. 2,917-11-0 as penalty for quarters ending June 30, 1949 to March 31, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: For the quarters ending June 30, 1949, to March 31, 1954, the appellant paid Rs. 1,17,869-80 as tax and Rs. 2,917-11-0 as penalty.

facts.text: Total amount paid by appellants as tax and penalty was Rs. 1,20,787-3-6.

anchor.surface_text: The tax so assessed under the diverse orders of assessment was paid from time to time.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Orissa High Court on August 9, 1954 relying on Gannon Dunkerley Co. Ltd. v. State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon the judgment, of the Madras High Court in Gannon Dunkerly Co. Ltd . v. State of Madras 1 , the appellant applied on August 9, 1954, to the High Court of Judicature, Orissa

facts.text: Appellant sought declaration that provisions of Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 authorising sales tax on works contracts were ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: for  a  a declaration that the provision of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 authorising imposition of the sales tax on a turnover of works companytracts and repair works were ultra vires the State Legislature

facts.text: Appellant sought declaration that assessments were illegal and refund of Rs. 1,20,787-3-6.

anchor.surface_text: b  a declaration that the assessment made by the State Sales Tax Authorities on the appellants works companytracts which had resulted in payment of Rs. 1,20,787-3-6 by was of sales tax and penalties

facts.text: Orissa High Court declared assessments not in accordance with law following State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley.

anchor.surface_text: Following the judgment of this Court in the State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerly , Co., Ltd. 1  which companyfirmed the decision of the Madras High Court in 5 S.T.C. 216, the High Court declared

facts.text: High Court directed no steps to realise arrears of sales tax on those contracts.

anchor.surface_text: that the assessment of sales tax was number in accordance with law and directed that numbersteps, either by certificate proceedings or otherwise should be taken to realise the arrears of sales tax

facts.text: High Court directed refund of tax paid if not barred under s.14 of Orissa Sales Tax Act 1947 on date of filing.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also directed refund of tax paid, if recovery thereof was number barred under 8.14 of the Orissa Sales Tax Act 1947 on the date of the filing of the application.

facts.text: High Court directed Sales Tax Authorities to revise assessments in light of Supreme Court decision for pending assessments.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also directed the Sales Tax Authorities to revise the assessments made in the light of the decision of this Court in respect of assessments made after the date of the petition.

facts.text: Appellants appealed to Supreme Court challenging High Court order on refund barred by limitation under s.14.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have appealed to this Court with special leave challenging the order in so far as their claim for refund is partially declared to be barred by the rule of limitation prescribed by ff. 14

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by Shah J. on October 26, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. October 26. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Section 14 of Orissa Sales Tax Act 1947 requires refund application within 24 months of assessment order or 12 months of final order.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947, provides The Collector shall, in the prescribed manner, refund to a dealer applying in this behalf any amount of tax paid by such dealer in excess ... Provided that numberclaim to refund ... within twenty-four months from the date on which the order of assessment was passed or within twelve months of the final order

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.14 of Orissa Sales Tax Act not ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s.14 of the Act are therefore number ultra vires the State Legislature.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Art.226 petition for refund subject to restrictions in s.14.

anchor.surface_text: The petition in the present case is for enforcement of the liability of the Collector imposed by statute to refund a-tax illegally companylected and it was maintainable but it can only be allowed subject to the restrictions which have been imposed by the Legislature.

facts.text: Supreme Court modified High Court order to refund tax if assessment order within 24 months of August 9, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: That part of the sales tax which has been paid by Messrs. Burmah Construction Co. shall be refunded by the State of Orissa to the Burmah Construction companypany if the order of assessment pursuant to which payment was made was within 24 months of the date on which the petition was filed in the High Court, namely, 9th of August, 1954.

facts.text: Orissa Sales Tax Act enacted under item 48 List II Seventh Schedule Government of India Act 1935.

anchor.surface_text: the orissa Sales Tax Act was enacted by the Orissa legislature in exercise of the Legislative authority companyferred upon it by item 48 of List II of the Seventh Schedule of the Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: Without deciding whether the Burmah Construction Co. has the right to recover the balance of the amount of the tax paid by other appropriate proceedings, the claim to recover the balance of the tax paid is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court normally does number entertain a petition under Art. 226 of the companystitution to enforce a civil liability arising out of a breach of companytract or a tort to pay and amount of money due to the claimant and leaves it to the aggrieved party to agitate the question in a civil suit filed for that purpose. But an order for payment of money may sometimes be made in a petition under Art. 226 of the companystitution against the State or against an officer of the State to enforce a statutory obligation.

concepts.interpretation: Art. 226 allows directions for payment to enforce statutory obligations against State, unlike ordinary civil claims.

anchor.surface_text: The power to legislate with respect to a tax. comprehends the power to impose the tax, to prescribe machinery for collecting the tax, to designate the officers by whom the liability may be enforced and to prescribe the authority, obligations and indemnity of those officers. The diverse heads of legislation in the Schedule to the constitution demarcate the periphery of legislative competence and include all matters which are ancillary or subsidiary to the primary head.

concepts.interpretation: Power to legislate on tax includes ancillary matters such as refund procedures and time limitations thereon; applied to uphold s.14.

holdings.text: The provisions of s.14 of the Act are therefore not ultra vires the State Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s.14 of the Act are therefore number ultra vires the State Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative power over taxes on sale of goods under item 48 List II Govt of India Act 1935 includes ancillary and subsidiary matters such as procedures for refund of improperly collected tax and time limitations thereon, following State of Orissa v. Orient Paper Mills Ltd.

holdings.text: A petition under Art. 226 for enforcement of statutory liability to refund illegally collected tax is maintainable but subject to legislative restrictions like those in s.14.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court numbermally does number entertain a petition under Art. 226 of the companystitution to enforce a civil liability arising out of a breach of companytract or a tort to pay and amount of money due to the claimant and leaves it to the aggrieved party to agitate the question in a civil suit filed for that purpose. But an order for payment of money may sometimes be made in a petition under Art. 226 of the companystitution against the State or against an officer of the State to enforce a statutory obligation. The petition in the present case is for enforcement of the liability of the Collector imposed by statute to refund a-tax illegally companylected and it was maintainable but it can only be allowed subject to the restrictions which have been imposed by the Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 226 allows enforcement of statutory obligations against State unlike ordinary civil claims, but claimant cannot ignore statutory restrictions when seeking to enforce the statutory right itself.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in restricting the order of refund in the petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the High Court was right in restricting the order of refund in the petition under Art. 226 of the companystitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition enforces s.14 obligation hence bound by its limitations; cannot selectively rely on statutory right ignoring restrictions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court numbermally does number entertain a petition under Art. 226 of the companystitution to enforce a civil liability arising out of a breach of companytract or a tort to pay and amount of money due to the claimant and leaves it to the aggrieved party to agitate the question in a civil suit filed for that purpose. But an order for payment of money may sometimes be made in a petition under Art. 226 of the companystitution against the State or against an officer of the State to enforce a statutory obligation. The petition in the present case is for enforcement of the liability of the Collector imposed by statute to refund a-tax illegally companylected and it was maintainable but it can only be allowed subject to the restrictions which have been imposed by the Legislature.
